case_vignette: A 45-year-old-man with a past medical history of knee pain and hypertension complains of dark spot on the lower lip and hands that develop whenever he takes certain oral medications. He states the rash has been ongoing for several years, and usually begins as a pink spot with a darker brown-black center. He denies any bleeding or ulceration at the site.  Current medications includes naproxen, multivitamins, and metoprolol.   Physical examination reveals a well demarcated red-purple patch with a darker red-violaceous center on the dorsal hands and lower lip. The patch is non-painful.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a dark spot on my lower lip and hands that appears whenever I take certain medications.
What medications cause this dark spot to appear?
I notice the spots develop when I take some oral medications, but I'm not exactly sure which ones are responsible.
Which medications have you been taking regularly that may cause these dark spots?
I've been taking naproxen, multivitamins, and metoprolol regularly.
Which of these medications consistently causes the dark spots on your lower lip and hands?
I'm not sure which specific medication is causing the dark spots.
Which medication was recently started or changed in dosage before the appearance of these dark spots?
I can't recall any specific medication that was started or changed in dosage before the spots appeared.
Have you noticed any family members with similar dark spots on their lower lip or hands?
No, I haven't noticed any family members with similar dark spots.
Final Diagnosis: Medication-induced pigmentation.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with dark spots on their lower lip and hands that appear whenever they take certain medications. The patient notices the spots developing when taking some oral medications, but is not exactly sure which ones are responsible. The patient has been taking naproxen, multivitamins, and metoprolol regularly and is unsure which specific medication is causing the dark spots. The patient cannot recall any specific medication that was started or changed in dosage before the spots appeared and has not noticed any family members with similar dark spots.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The correct diagnosis is Fixed Drug Eruption.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The final diagnosis is likely Drug-Induced Pigmentation or Drug-Induced Hemorrhage, possibly due to Naproxen. However, a definitive diagnosis would require further testing or consultation with a dermatologist.
trial_0.summarized_mcq: The correct diagnosis is Fixed Drug Eruption.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Drug-induced melanocytic hyperpigmentation. However, it is important to note that the specific medication causing the symptoms cannot be definitively determined based on the given information. Further investigation and possibly a medication challenge test may be necessary to identify the offending agent.

I have a dark spot on my lower lip and hands that shows up whenever I take certain medications.

I'm not exactly sure which ones cause the spots, they just develop when I take some of my oral medications.

Final Diagnosis: Naproxen-induced Melanocytic Hyperpigmentation.
